content.question: During a chemical reaction, the rate of change of the amount of the chemical remaining is proportional to the amount remaining. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the amount of the chemical is 12 moles. At time <math alttext="t equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the amount of the chemical is 4 moles. At what time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the amount of the chemical 3 moles? (A mole is a unit of measure used in chemistry.)

choices.label: <math alttext="3 times the square root of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><msqrt><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the fraction with numerator 4 times the natural log of 3, and denominator the natural log of 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the fraction with numerator 4 times the natural log of 4, and denominator the natural log of 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="the fraction with numerator 4 times the natural log of 4, and denominator the natural log of 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: Skill 3.G: Confirm that solutions are accurate and appropriate.
